}} 'Club AtlÃ©tico Newell's Old Boys' is an Argentine sports club based in
Rosario, Santa Fe. The club was founded on November 3, 1903, and is named after
Isaac Newell, one of the pioneers of Argentine football. Newell's is best known
for its football team, that plays in the Argentine Primera DivisiÃ³n, the top
division of the Argentine league system.

Originally member of Rosario's Football Association, Newell's affiliated to the
Argentine Football Association (AFA) in 1939. They have won AFA's Primera
DivisiÃ³n five times throughout their history, the first being in the 1974
Metropolitano and the last in the 2004 Clausura. Newell's has also been twice
Copa Libertadores runner-up (in 1988 and 1992).

The club's football stadium is the Estadio Marcelo Bielsa, named after the
team's former player and manager Marcelo Bielsa (twice champion, and runner-up
of one Copa Libertadores). Newell's plays the Rosario derby against Rosario
Central, a club with which they have a huge historical rivalry.

Newell's is also notable for its youth divisions, being the club with most
national titles in AFA's youth tournaments. [http://archivo.lacapital.com.a-
r/2005/05/26/ovacion/noticia_198426.shtml "Newell's es el equipo rÃ©cord en
inferiores de AFA"] in La Capital. Players from the club's youths who have
represented Argentina at World Cups are Gabriel Batistuta, AmÃ©rico Gallego,
Jorge Valdano, Gabriel Heinze, Roberto Sensini, Mauricio Pocchettino and Maxi
RodrÃ­guez, among others. Lionel Messi also played in the club's youths, but left
at a young age to Barcelona to seek treatment for his growth hormone deficiency,
while Diego Maradona played briefly for the first team in 1993 (5 games).

Other sports practised at the club are basketball, boxing, field hockey, martial
arts, roller skating and volleyball.
